Windstream customers, including Cleveland County Schools, are experiencing issues throughout the county. We certainly realize this is not helpful during the first week of school.

Again, this is a service provider issue and we hope the repair happens quickly. However, please feel free to connect with your teachers via email. The email addresses can be located on the respective school websites at www.clevelandcountyschools.org/schools.

shared_text:
Matt Harris is with Kaye Cherry Harris.
July 16 at 12:04 AM ¬∑

The announcement below was made today during our state‚Äôs Career and Technical Education Virtual Teacher Conference.

I am so very proud of Kaye and what she does to support students in Career and Technical Education. She has served as a leader in both our NC Agriculture Teachers Association as well as the NC Association of Career and Technical Educators. In addition, she has worked for years providing online curriculum products that have helped countless agricultural teachers across this state while also developing a strong agriculture program at our school.

Kaye is not one to talk about her accomplishments but I proud to do so. I know that our students in CTE are better off because of her work. Congratulations Kaye Cherry Harris North Carolina CTE Teacher of the Year.
text:
Matt Harris is with Kaye Cherry Harris.
July 16 at 12:04 AM ¬∑

The announcement below was made today during our state‚Äôs Career and Technical Education Virtual Teacher Conference.

I am so very proud of Kaye and what she does to support students in Career and Technical Education. She has served as a leader in both our NC Agriculture Teachers Association as well as the NC Association of Career and Technical Educators. In addition, she has worked for years providing online curriculum products that have helped countless agricultural teachers across this state while also developing a strong agriculture program at our school.

Kaye is not one to talk about her accomplishments but I proud to do so. I know that our students in CTE are better off because of her work. Congratulations Kaye Cherry Harris North Carolina CTE Teacher of the Year.

post_text:
Governor Cooper issued a joint statement with the NC Department of Health and Human Services (NCDHHS), the NC State Board of Education (NCSBE) and the NC Department of Public Instruction (NCDPI), announcing that after months of careful work, the state is moving forward with implementing Plan B for reopening schools.

PLAN B is 50% of students on campus for face to face learning at a time.

The primary focus of our school community is to continue providing the best educational experiences possible for our students while creating the healthiest and safest environment for our students and staff. While we understand this pandemic has created lots of obstacles, we remain steadfast in our approach to serve our students, schools, and communities.

Cleveland County Schools will begin to finalize plans as we prepare for August 17th. Over the next few days and weeks, students and parents can expect additional information related to scheduling, blended learning, and expectations for the 2020-2021 school year.
text:
Governor Cooper issued a joint statement with the NC Department of Health and Human Services (NCDHHS), the NC State Board of Education (NCSBE) and the NC Department of Public Instruction (NCDPI), announcing that after months of careful work, the state is moving forward with implementing Plan B for reopening schools.

PLAN B is 50% of students on campus for face to face learning at a time.

The primary focus of our school community is to continue providing the best educational experiences possible for our students while creating the healthiest and safest environment for our students and staff. While we understand this pandemic has created lots of obstacles, we remain steadfast in our approach to serve our students, schools, and communities.

Cleveland County Schools will begin to finalize plans as we prepare for August 17th. Over the next few days and weeks, students and parents can expect additional information related to scheduling, blended learning, and expectations for the 2020-2021 school year.

post_text: "The COVID-19 public health crisis and the closure of school facilities as instructional settings for the remainder of the 2019-20 school year have created questions related to high school graduations. post_text:
If you are experiencing hardships and need additional help finding food for your child (or children) along with what our schools are already providing, text FOODNC to 877-877. You will be asked to enter your address. You will receive a text back with the location of the closest meal sites and serving times. You can also call 2-1-1 to speak with an operator 24/7 who can help locate meal sites and other resources.

Please feel free to forward this information along to anyone in need of assistance.

post_text:
The Governor of North Carolina extended the Executive Order that all schools throughout the state will be closed for students until at least May 15.

COVID-19 has created lots of uncertainty over the past ten days. This past week, Cleveland County Schools opened 22 child feeding stations and provided 8 Wi-Fi hotspots in our community. While we have been able to provide some answers and solutions, many questions and concerns still exist. We will continue to provide updates via Facebook as well as our website at teamccs.org/coronavirus.

Cleveland County Schools is committed to our students, schools, and community, and together we will overcome these challenges and continue to make Cleveland County a great place to live, work, learn, and play.
text:
The Governor of North Carolina extended the Executive Order that all schools throughout the state will be closed for students until at least May 15.

COVID-19 has created lots of uncertainty over the past ten days. This past week, Cleveland County Schools opened 22 child feeding stations and provided 8 Wi-Fi hotspots in our community. While we have been able to provide some answers and solutions, many questions and concerns still exist. We will continue to provide updates via Facebook as well as our website at teamccs.org/coronavirus.

Cleveland County Schools is committed to our students, schools, and community, and together we will overcome these challenges and continue to make Cleveland County a great place to live, work, learn, and play.

post_text:
In an effort to provide educational connectivity, the Cleveland County Schools Technology Services Team has provided public wireless access (WiFi) via outdoor hotspots at Bethware Elementary, Burns Middle, Casar Elementary, Crest Middle, James Love Elementary, Kings Mountain High, Shelby High, and Township Three Elementary. Any device should be able to connect to the guest CSS-BYOD network without the need for an access password.

As shown in the link below, each free WiFi location has a designated parking area in which users can experience the best signal. Please remain in your vehicles during use. This service is available seven days a week between the hours of 7 a.m. and 10 p.m.

Visit the following link to view the WiFi maps.
https://www.teamccs.org/freepublicwifi

post_text:
School Nutrition Services will provide free meals beginning Monday, March 16th - Mondays through Fridays from 11:30 a.m. to 1 p.m. at all school sites except Burns High, Crest High, Kings Mountain High, Shelby Middle, North Shelby, and East Elementary as each of those locations are near other meal sites.

During the daily pickup opportunity (between 11:30 a.m. to 1 p.m. at the front of each school unless directed otherwise), lunch will be provided as well as a breakfast for the following morning.

The meals are available to any child or teen ages 2 to 18 years old at any meal site of their choosing. We especially encourage all of our students to participate in this program while school is out during this time.

For additional details regarding the meal program, please visit the CCS School Nutrition Services website at www.clevelandcountynutrition.org.

post_text:
The Governor of North Carolina issued an Executive Order that all schools throughout the state will be closed for students for two weeks beginning Monday, March 16, 2020. Therefore, Cleveland County Schools is closed for students beginning Monday, March 16, 2020. Please continue to check our website for updated information over the next two weeks.

We will continue to provide you with additional updates on a variety of educational, instructional, and operational information.

The Cleveland County Board of Education will meet in Emergency Session on Sunday, March 15, at 4:30 p.m. at Central Services (400 West Marion Street of Shelby).

Therefore, Cleveland County Schools is closed for students beginning Monday, March 16, 2020. Please continue to check our website for updated information over the next two weeks.

We will continue to provide you with additional updates on a variety of educational, instructional, and operational information.

The Cleveland County Board of Education will meet in Emergency Session on Sunday, March 15, at 4:30 p.m. at Central Services (400 West Marion Street of Shelby).

Cleveland County Library System
March 9 at 3:58 PM ¬∑

The Countdown to Census 2020 is on! The Census survey will ask questions about the number of people living in your household. You will need to know the gender, race, age and birthdate of everyone living in your house in order to complete the Census. Your Census information will NOT be used against you. It will NOT be sold for marketing purposes and it will NOT be given to the IRS, law enforcement or immigration.

shared_text:
Cleveland County Government
March 4 at 7:29 PM ¬∑

PLEASE SHARE: The U.S. Census is a survey of everyone living in every town, every city and every state. Conducted once every 10 years, the Census determines how billions in federal funding is allocated for healthcare, jobs, schools and roads based on population. We will lose $1,838 for every person who is NOT counted in the Census. Remember, I count. You count. Everyone in Cleveland County should get counted in Census 2020.

post_text:
As you may know, the weather has created excitement surrounding our county. As we review the forecast and consult with local Emergency Management, we believe the temperatures will rise by our normal dismissal time and the snow will turn to rain. We feel that it is safer to dismiss school later than at the current time.

Again, our plan is to dismiss at the normal time to ensure all students and staff will have safe roads to travel home for the weekend. However, we wanted to keep you in the loop as we are certainly monitoring weather and road conditions. If there are any changes to our current plan, we will make sure everyone is informed through our typical methods of communication.
text:
As you may know, the weather has created excitement surrounding our county. As we review the forecast and consult with local Emergency Management, we believe the temperatures will rise by our normal dismissal time and the snow will turn to rain. We feel that it is safer to dismiss school later than at the current time.

Again, our plan is to dismiss at the normal time to ensure all students and staff will have safe roads to travel home for the weekend. However, we wanted to keep you in the loop as we are certainly monitoring weather and road conditions. If there are any changes to our current plan, we will make sure everyone is informed through our typical methods of communication.
